'''''C. orellanus''''' |binomial=''Cortinarius rubellus'' |binomial_authority=[[Mordecai Cubitt Cooke|Cooke]] |binomial2=''Cortinarius orellanus'' |binomial2_authority=[[Elias Magnus Fries|Fries]] }} {{mycomorphbox |name=Cortinarius rubellus |whichGills=adnexed |capShape=umbonate |hymeniumType=gills |stipeCharacter=cortina |ecologicalType=mycorrhizal |sporePrintColor=brown |howEdible=deadly }} The '''Orellani''' are a group of seven related species in the genus ''[[Cortinarius]]'' that have been classified as a section of the subgenus ''Leprocybe'' or a subgenus in their own right.{{cite journal |author=Gasparini B |title=''Cortinarius'' subgenus ''Orellani'' in Australia and in the world |journal=Australasian Mycologist |year=2004 |volume=23 |issue=2 |pages=62–76 |url=http://media.wix.com/ugd/86d4e0_8dc7de09f7b74fb28367b59a29975599.pdf}} They are among world's most [[Mushroom poisoning#Poisonous species|poisonous mushrooms]] as they contain the highly toxic compound [[orellanine]]. The best-known species are the '''deadly webcap''' (''[[Cortinarius rubellus]]'', formerly also known as ''C. speciosissimus'' or ''C. orellanoides'') and the '''fool's webcap''', ''[[Cortinarius orellanus|C. orellanus]]''. The mushrooms' characteristics are quite common, making them difficult to identify, which often leads to [[Death|fatal]] poisonings. Young examples of the species often have a veil between the cap of the mushroom and the stem. This veil looks like a cobweb, hence the name. The veil however partially or completely disappears in older specimens. Some other characteristics for each of the mushrooms are given below. ==Descriptions== ===Deadly webcap ''(Cortinarius rubellus)''=== ''[[Spore]] color'': Rusty brown to orange
''Cap'': 3–7 cm rusty brown to orange. Often has a steeper and darker colored elevation at the top of the cap, but this varies greatly from specimen to specimen
''[[Gill (mushroom)|Gills]]'': Wide gaps between the gills which can be, but are not necessarily, connected to the stem
''Location'': Rare, but common in temperate parts of northern [[Europe]]. Has been encountered as far north as Finnish Lapland.
''[[Habitat (ecology)|Habitat]]'': [[pine]] woods with [[Soil pH|acidic]] soil
''Other details'': Young specimens contain a pale web between the cap and the stem. Sometimes parts of this web can be seen as a yellow ring on the stem or at the edge of the cap. The fruiting body of the mushroom blossoms from mid-summer to late autumn. ''Cortinarius rainierensis'', described in 1950 by [[Alexander H. Smith|Alex H. Smith]] and [[Daniel Elliot Stuntz]] from material collected [[Mount Rainier National Park]],{{cite journal |author=Smith AH, Stuntz DE |year= 1950 |title= New or noteworthy Fungi from Mt. Rainier National Park | journal= Mycologia |volume= 42|issue= 1 | pages= 80–134 |doi=10.2307/3755245|jstor= 3755245 }} is a synonym.[http://www.pnwfungi.org/index.php/pnwfungi/article/viewFile/1021/662] ===Fool's webcap ''(Cortinarius orellanus)''=== ''Spore color'': Rusty brown to orange
''Cap'': 3–8.5 cm, concave
''Gills'': Similar to those of the deadly webcap
''Location'': Common throughout Europe, rare in the northern parts of Europe. Has been observed as far north as southern [[Norway]]
''Habitat'': In forests, around trees where the soil is [[alkaline]] or acidic
''Other details'': Young specimens of the fool's webcap also contain a web between the cap and the stem that partially or completely disappears as the specimen ages. ==Toxicity== {{Main|Orellanine}} The deadly webcap and the fool's webcap both contain the toxin [[orellanin]] and orellin, orellinin{{Cite book | url=https://books.google.com/?id=iaZzj4Rn0QYC&pg=PA501&lpg=PA501&dq=orelline+orellanine+orellinine | title=Handbook of Natural Toxins: Toxicology of Plant and Fungal Compounds| isbn=9780824783754| last1=Keeler| first1=R. F.| date=1991-03-01}} and Cortinarin A,B,C.{{Cite book | url=https://books.google.com/?id=iaZzj4Rn0QYC&pg=PA507&lpg=PA507&dq=cortinarin |title = Handbook of Natural Toxins: Toxicology of Plant and Fungal Compounds|isbn = 9780824783754|last1 = Keeler|first1 = R. F.|date = 1991-03-01}} A characteristic of orellanin poisoning is the long latency; the first symptoms usually don't appear until 2–3 days after ingestion and can in some cases take as long as 3 weeks. The first symptoms of orellanin poisoning are similar to the common [[Influenza|flu]] ([[nausea]], vomiting, stomach pains, [[headaches]], etc.). These symptoms are followed by early stages of [[renal failure]] (immense thirst, frequent urination, pain on and around the [[kidneys]]), and eventually decreased or nonexistent urine output and other symptoms of renal failure occur. If left untreated, death will follow. There is no known [[antidote]] against orellanin poisoning, but early hospitalization and treatment can sometimes prevent serious injuries and usually prevent death. If you suspect orellanin poisoning, seek emergency medical attention. Both of these mushrooms can be confused with each other and many incidents of [[mushroom poisoning]] have occurred where inexperienced [[Mushroom hunting|mushroom hunters]] have confused these mushrooms with [[edible mushroom]]s, such as the [[Cantharellus|chanterelle]], or [[Psilocybin mushrooms|hallucinogenic mushrooms]].{{cite journal |vauthors=Franz M, Regele H, Kirchmair M, etal |title=Magic mushrooms: hope for a 'cheap high' resulting in end-stage renal failure|journal=Nephrol. Dial. Transplant.|volume=11|issue=11|pages=2324–27|date=November 1996|pmid=8941602|url=http://ndt.oxfordjournals.org/content/11/11/2324.full.pdf|doi=10.1093/oxfordjournals.ndt.a027160}} Extreme care should be taken when picking mushrooms like the [[Cantharellus tubaeformis|cleaned funnel chanterelles]] as these mushrooms share the same habitat as the deadly webcap and the fool's webcap. In Poland during the 1950s there was a small epidemic where over 100 people became ill. What caused the illness remained a mystery until 1952 when Polish physician Stanisław Grzymala discovered that everyone suffering from the illness, which by then had claimed several lives, had eaten the mushroom ''[[Cortinarius orellanus]]''.See: * Alina Skirgiełło and Andrzej Nespiak (1957) "Erfahrungen mit ''Dermocybe orellana'' (Fr.) in Polen: A. ''Cortinarius'' (''Dermocybe'') ''orellanus'' Fr. non Quél. — cause d'intoxications fongiques en Pologne en 1952-55" (Experiences with ''Dermocybe orellana'' (Fr.) in Poland: A. ''Cortinarius'' (''Dermocybe'') ''orellanus'' Fr. non Quél. — cause of mushroom poisoning in Poland in 1952-55) ''Zeitschrift für Pilzkunde'' (Journal for Mycology), vol. 23, pages 138-139. * Stanisław Grzymala (1957) "Erfahrungen mit ''Dermocybe orellana'' (Fr.) in Polen: B. Massenvergiftung durch den Orangefuchsigen Hautkopf. (Experiences with ''Dermocybe orellana'' (Fr.) in Poland: B. Mass poisoning by the orange-red web-cap), ''Zeitschrift für Pilzkunde'', vol. 23, pages 139-142.{{cite book|last=Spoerke|first= David G.|author2=Barry H Rumack |title=Handbook of Mushroom Poisoning: Diagnosis and Treatment|publisher=[[CRC Press]]|year=1994|page= [https://books.google.com/books?id=WPWsZNvOqVAC&pg=PA250#v=onepage&q&f=false 250]|isbn=0-8493-0194-7|title-link= Handbook of Mushroom Poisoning: Diagnosis and Treatment}} The {{LD50}} of orellanin in mice is 12–20 mg per kg body weight. From cases of orellanine-related mushroom poisoning in humans it seems that the lethal dose for humans is considerably lower. Several more mushrooms in the genus ''Cortinarius'' are suspected to contain orellanin or other deadly toxins. Among them are ''[[Cortinarius callisteus]]'' and ''[[Cortinarius limonius]]''. ===Notable poisonings=== [[Nicholas Evans]], author of ''The Horse Whisperer'', his wife [[Charlotte Gordon Cumming]], and two other relatives were accidentally poisoned in September 2008 after consuming ''Cortinarius rubellus'' and/or ''Cortinarius speciosissimus'' that they gathered on holiday.{{cite news|url= https://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/books/8675690/Nicholas-Evans-I-wanted-to-die.-It-was-so-grim.html|place=London|work=[[The Daily Telegraph]]|first=Elizabeth|last=Grice|title=Nicholas Evans: 'I wanted to die. It was so grim'|date=August 2, 2011}} Although the poisoning was non-lethal, Evans and the others suffered severe renal damage and had to undergo [[kidney dialysis]].{{Cite journal | last1 = Evans | first1 = N. | last2 = Hamilton | first2 = A. | last3 = Bello-Villalba | first3 = M. J. | last4 = Bingham | first4 = C. | title = Irreversible renal damage from accidental mushroom poisoning | doi = 10.1136/bmj.e5262 | journal = BMJ | volume = 345 | pages = e5262 | year = 2012 | pmid = 22885396| pmc = }}{{Cite news |url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2008/09/02/horse-whisperer-author-po_n_123268.html |title="Horse Whisperer" Author Poisoned By Mushrooms |agency=[[Associated Press]] |work=[[The Huffington Post]] |date=September 2, 2008}} All four victims were informed that they would require [[kidney transplant]]s in the future. Several years later, Evans received a kidney donated by his daughter, Lauren.{{cite news|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-2015392/Author-Horse-Whisperer-poisoned-eating-mushrooms-kidney-transplant-daughter.html|place=London|work=Daily Mail|title=Author of Horse Whisperer poisoned by eating mushrooms has kidney transplant from daughter|date=July 16, 2011}}{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2010/sep/16/wild-mushroom-picking|title=How to pick wild mushrooms|first=Phil |last=Daoust|work=[[The Guardian]]|date=September 16, 2010|location=London}} ==See also== {{Portal|Fungi}} *[[List of deadly fungi]] *[[Mushroom hunting]] *[[Mushroom poisoning]] ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== *[http://www.mycologia.org/cgi/content/full/94/5/752 The presence of orellanine in spores and basidiocarp from ''Cortinarius orellanus'' and ''Cortinarius rubellus''] *[https://www.youtube.com/results?search_query=Cortinarius+rubellus&oq=Cortinarius+rubellus&gs_l=youtube.3...4732.4732.0.5886.1.1.0.0.0.0.148.148.0j1.1.0...0.0...1ac.1.C6DctQoP3V8 Videos of ''Cortinarius orellanus'' on YouTube] {{Commons|Cortinarius orellanus}} [[Category:Poisonous fungi]] [[Category:Deadly fungi]] [[Category:Cortinarius]]
